awd_titl_txt: IRES Track I: Model-Based Design, 3D-Printing, and Evaluation of Assistive Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this award is to establish an international research and education partnership between the University of Michigan (U-M) and University of Bologna (UniBo) in Italy.  The proposed work is envisioned to improve the quality-of-life of people with disabilities and their caregivers, transform the knee-ankle-foot-orthosis care to data-based diagnosis and model-based design and 3D-printing, and provide an international research experience to students. The goal of this collaboration is to provide a high-quality international research experience to University of Michigan students to increase student diversity and retention and advance students' ability in and knowledge of culture, globalization, leadership, teamwork, and communication. The key intellectual merit of this collaboration is in the model-based design, 3D-printing, and evaluation of individualized assistive devices. The project will utilize technical knowledge gained from University of Michigan and will improve individualized assistive devices such as the knee-ankle-foot orthosis, a brace that helps people with leg instabilities to walk. 

The scientific objective of this award is to establish an international research and education partnership between the University of Michigan (U-M) and University of Bologna (UniBo) in Italy on the model-based design, 3D-printing, and evaluation of individualized assistive devices (IADs). The project is focused on the advancements in 3D-printing and wearable sensors that enable the design and fabrication of assistive devices for individual needs.  Patient-specific biomechanical models will be developed to analyze the motions and forces associated with the daily activities of a patient. For example, from models of patient-specific knee joint motion, compliant 3D-printed knee joints will be analyzed and designed to improve the function of individual assistive devices.  Combined metal 3D-printing, precision machining, and mechanical testing will be used to fabricate and test the compliant knee joint.  Finally, the knee-ankle-foot-orthosis devices fabricated by conventional and 3D-printing methods will be evaluated on patients in clinic and during daily activities. Specifically, this project aims to design, fabricate, and evaluate an individualized knee-ankle-foot-orthosis (KAFO) with metal and plastic 3D-printed parts. Students will study four research topics related to the KAFO: (1) biomechanical quantification of activities and lifestyles of KAFO patients, (2) analysis and design of a patient-specific compliant knee joint, (3) manufacturing of compliant knee joint, and (4) evaluation of the patient-specific KAFO.

The broader impact of the proposed work in design, 3D-printing, and evaluation of personalized assistive devices is to re-establish the quality-of-life of people with disabilities by restoring normal joint motion and function. Personalized assistive devices with good fit and quick delivery can greatly benefit patients as well as their caregivers. Further, tailoring the function of these devices to the patient improves their ability to ambulate and reduces the chances of reinjury. The transformative aspects of this project are the mass production of custom assistive devices and the long-term monitoring of the gait and mobility of assistive device users for physical and psychological diagnosis and prevention of fall and other accidents. The knowledge and biomechanical models can improve the design practice and evaluation of the efficacy of a broad range of assistive devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
A National Science Foundation International Research Experiences for Students project has established a research partnership between the University of Michigan and the University of Bologna in Italy on model-based design, 3D-printing, and evaluation for individualized assistive devices.  This project has expanded our existing collaboration to recruit students to conduct joint research at four University of Bologna centers of excellence on Occupational Medicine Group, Group of Robotics, Automation and Articular Biomechanics, Center for Advanced Laser Manufacturing, and Lab of Movement Analysis and Functional-Clinical Evaluation of Prosthesis.  University of Bologna, founded in 1088, is recognized as the oldest university in the world and excellent in engineering and medicine.  University of Bologna also has outstanding research facilities and a great learning environment for students.  A cohort of six students conducted research for two months at Bologna in summer 2019.  In 2020-2022, due to Covid, this collaboration continued virtually throughout the year in three projects on personalized knee implant with dynamic magnetic renounce imaging (MRI) measurements, low-cost fuse filament fabrication of Nylon for personalized assistive devices, and biomechanics modeling of the ankle foot orthosis.  In the first project, University of Bologna has a unique MRI machine which has the time resolution to measure the dynamic shape of the knee in several instances while walking at a regular path within the MRI chamber.  Based on this unique MRI measured data set, the custom shape of an artificial knee for a person can be designed for fabrication using the metal additive manufacturing (3D-printing) method.  This project advanced the technology for personalized artificial knee implant design and manufacturing.  Two students visited the University of Bologna in 2022 to continue the training and advancements of this technology to improve the quality of personalized knee implants.  In the second project, Nylon is an engineering plastic material with high strength and ductility.  It is ideal for additive manufacturing of components for assistive devices.  Nylon also has a low glass transition temperature at about 65 degree C, which can be reached to improve the bonding between layers of Nylon in a thermally insulated chamber of the fused filament fabrication (FFF) machine for 3D-printing.  We have tested this concept by printing tensile specimens using FFF under various chamber temperatures and measuring the tensile strength and material crystalline structure of these specimens.  This concept has been validated and opens a new way for rapid, low-cost fabrication of personalized assistive devices.  In the third project, a compressive biomechanics model has been developed using the inertia measurement unit measured motion data as the input to determine the joint angles and walking gait of the lower limb of assistive device users.  The health metrics of walking of assistive device users can be quantified to provide the feedback for design of better ankle foot orthoses. 

 


Last Modified: 07/23/2023
Modified by: Albert J Shih

por.por_txt_cntn:
A National Science Foundation International Research Experiences for Students project has established a research partnership between the University of Michigan and the University of Bologna in Italy on model-based design, 3D-printing, and evaluation for individualized assistive devices.  This project has expanded our existing collaboration to recruit students to conduct joint research at four University of Bologna centers of excellence on Occupational Medicine Group, Group of Robotics, Automation and Articular Biomechanics, Center for Advanced Laser Manufacturing, and Lab of Movement Analysis and Functional-Clinical Evaluation of Prosthesis.  University of Bologna, founded in 1088, is recognized as the oldest university in the world and excellent in engineering and medicine.  University of Bologna also has outstanding research facilities and a great learning environment for students.  A cohort of six students conducted research for two months at Bologna in summer 2019.  In 2020-2022, due to Covid, this collaboration continued virtually throughout the year in three projects on personalized knee implant with dynamic magnetic renounce imaging (MRI) measurements, low-cost fuse filament fabrication of Nylon for personalized assistive devices, and biomechanics modeling of the ankle foot orthosis.  In the first project, University of Bologna has a unique MRI machine which has the time resolution to measure the dynamic shape of the knee in several instances while walking at a regular path within the MRI chamber.  Based on this unique MRI measured data set, the custom shape of an artificial knee for a person can be designed for fabrication using the metal additive manufacturing (3D-printing) method.  This project advanced the technology for personalized artificial knee implant design and manufacturing.  Two students visited the University of Bologna in 2022 to continue the training and advancements of this technology to improve the quality of personalized knee implants.  In the second project, Nylon is an engineering plastic material with high strength and ductility.  It is ideal for additive manufacturing of components for assistive devices.  Nylon also has a low glass transition temperature at about 65 degree C, which can be reached to improve the bonding between layers of Nylon in a thermally insulated chamber of the fused filament fabrication (FFF) machine for 3D-printing.  We have tested this concept by printing tensile specimens using FFF under various chamber temperatures and measuring the tensile strength and material crystalline structure of these specimens.  This concept has been validated and opens a new way for rapid, low-cost fabrication of personalized assistive devices.  In the third project, a compressive biomechanics model has been developed using the inertia measurement unit measured motion data as the input to determine the joint angles and walking gait of the lower limb of assistive device users.  The health metrics of walking of assistive device users can be quantified to provide the feedback for design of better ankle foot orthoses.
